interactions.therapist: Hi Gabriel, you mentioned feeling easily frustrated over small things. Can you share a recent example?
interactions.gabriel: Sure. Last week, my laptop froze when I was editing some photos. I got so annoyed I just stopped working on it altogether.

interactions.therapist: That sounds frustrating. Did you feel like the frustration stayed with you for the rest of the day?
interactions.gabriel: Yeah, it kind of set the tone for the whole day. I kept snapping at little things after that.

interactions.therapist: Do you notice this happening often, or was it just a bad day?
interactions.gabriel: It happens more often lately. I know these are small problems, but they feel so much bigger in the moment.

interactions.therapist: How do you usually manage when you feel that way?
interactions.gabriel: I try to take a break or go for a walk, but it does not always help.

interactions.therapist: Have you noticed if the frustration is tied to certain times, like when you are tired or hungry?
interactions.gabriel: Probably when I am tired. By the end of the day, even small annoyances get to me.

interactions.therapist: That makes sense. Sometimes fatigue can make us more sensitive to stress. Have you tried writing down what triggers your frustration?
interactions.gabriel: No, I have not, but it might help to see if there are patterns.

interactions.therapist: That is a great idea. We can discuss what you notice next time.
You mentioned feeling like you are not making progress in life. Can you share what that means to you?
interactions.gabriel: I feel like I should be doing more. I moved here to start fresh, but it feels like I am just stuck in the same place.

interactions.therapist: What are some things you wanted to achieve with this fresh start?
interactions.gabriel: Building a social circle, maybe finding a better job, and feeling like I have a purpose.

interactions.therapist: Those are big goals. Have you noticed any small steps you have made toward them?
interactions.gabriel: Not really. I mean, I have met a few people and started exploring the city, but it does not feel like enough.

interactions.therapist: It sounds like you are setting very high expectations for yourself. Do you often feel like your efforts are not enough?
interactions.gabriel: All the time. Even when I try, it feels like I should be doing more.

interactions.therapist: That can be overwhelming. What if we focused on recognising one small success each day?
interactions.gabriel: Like what?

interactions.therapist: For example, going out to take photos or trying a new place in the city. Even small actions count as progress.
interactions.gabriel: I guess I could try that. It feels weird to celebrate such small things, though.

interactions.therapist: It might feel strange at first, but small wins can add up over time. Let us revisit this next week.
Gabriel, you mentioned food does not appeal to you like it used to. How often do you find yourself skipping meals?
interactions.gabriel: Most days, honestly. I just do not feel hungry, so I end up having something small or nothing at all.

interactions.therapist: Has this been happening for a long time, or is it a recent change?
interactions.gabriel: It started a few months ago, maybe around the time I moved. I used to enjoy cooking, but now it feels like a chore.

interactions.therapist: Do you notice if skipping meals affects your energy or mood?
interactions.gabriel: Definitely. I feel tired and irritable when I do not eat, but even then, it is hard to force myself to eat.

interactions.therapist: That makes sense. Have you tried keeping snacks or easy-to-prepare meals on hand?
interactions.gabriel: A little, but I still end up skipping meals more often than not.

interactions.therapist: What about foods you used to enjoy? Have you tried revisiting those?
interactions.gabriel: I have, but they do not taste the same anymore.

interactions.therapist: It sounds like food has lost some of its appeal. Sometimes, this can be tied to feeling low or stressed. Does that resonate with you?
interactions.gabriel: Maybe. It is just hard to care about meals when everything feels off.

interactions.therapist: That is understandable. Let us set a small goal to prepare or eat one balanced meal this week. How does that sound?
interactions.gabriel: I think I can do that.

interactions.therapist: You mentioned feeling awkward in social situations, even with friends. What is that like for you?
interactions.gabriel: It is like I do not know what to say. I feel out of place, even with people I have known for years.

interactions.therapist: Does this happen every time, or just in certain situations?
interactions.gabriel: Mostly with groups. One-on-one is easier, but even then, I feel like I say the wrong things.

interactions.therapist: How do you usually handle those feelings when they come up?
interactions.gabriel: I stay quiet or make up an excuse to leave early.

interactions.therapist: Do you feel better after leaving, or does it linger?
interactions.gabriel: It lingers. I replay the conversation in my head and think about all the things I could have done differently.

interactions.therapist: That sounds exhausting. Have you ever tried focusing on the positive parts of those interactions instead?
interactions.gabriel: Not really. I usually just focus on what went wrong.

interactions.therapist: What if next time, you try to find one thing that went well? Even something small, like saying hello or smiling at someone?
interactions.gabriel: I could try, but it is hard to notice those things in the moment.

interactions.therapist: It might take practice, but starting small can make a difference. Let us work on that together.
Gabriel, when you think about your current situation, do you focus more on what is going wrong or what is going right?
interactions.gabriel: Definitely what is going wrong. It is hard not to when it feels like I am not getting anywhere.

interactions.therapist: What about the positives, like moving to a new city? That is a big step.
interactions.gabriel: I guess, but it does not feel like a success since I am still struggling.

interactions.therapist: That is understandable, but even taking the step to move is an accomplishment. What motivated you to do it?
interactions.gabriel: I wanted a fresh start and a chance to figure things out, but it is not going how I hoped.

interactions.therapist: What are some small wins you have had since moving?
interactions.gabriel: I found a couple of good spots for photography, but that is about it.

interactions.therapist: That is a great win. What about your photography do you enjoy?
interactions.gabriel: I like capturing unique moments, like the way light hits a building. It feels satisfying when I get it right.

interactions.therapist: That is wonderful. Let us try focusing on more moments like that, where you feel satisfaction or pride. How does that sound?
interactions.gabriel: I can try, but it is hard to see those moments as progress.

interactions.therapist: Progress does not have to be big to matter. Let us work on recognising and building on these small successes together.
